Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analysis of the Geometric Properties of the SLE Curves
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Schramm-Loewner evolution (SLE) introduced by Oded Schramm in 1999 has been used with great success to prove many outstanding conjectures and predictions from Statistical Physics. The PI has been working on SLE for a number of years, and has made some important contributions to this area. The proposed project focuses on studying the geometric properties of the SLE curves of various kinds. To do this project, the PI will use the stochastic coupling technique he developed earlier. This technique is used to construct more than one SLE curve in single domain in such a way that the curves commute with each other. It was applied to prove the Duplantier's duality conjecture, the reversibility of chordal SLE and whole-plane SLE (for some parameters), and that it is possible to erase loops on a planar Brownian motion to get an SLE curve. In the proposed project, the PI will continue the application of the coupling technique. This includes constructing simple SLE loops on the Riemann sphere, proving the reversibility of the natural parametrization of SLE, and studying the behavior of SLE in multiply connected domains.

The proposed research plan will give people better understanding of the behavior of the SLE curves growing in simply and multiply connected domains. This will then increase understanding of a number of two-dimensional Statistical Physics lattice models (e.g. critical percolation, critical Ising model, Gaussian free field, and loop-erased random walk) in different kinds of domains since SLE have been identified as the scaling limits of these models. The project will also have significant impacts on Conformal Field Theory. A significant part of this proposal is its educational component. The PI will develop undergraduate courses on Probability and Complex Analysis at Michigan State University to include the newest development of the PI's research area. He will also teach specialized graduate courses on SLE, and involve graduate students in working under his supervision.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Schramm-Loewner evolution (SLE$_\kappa$), introduced by Oded Schramm in 1999, is a one-parameter ($\kappa\in(0,\infty)$) family of probability measures on non-self-crossing curves in plane domains. It has been shown that the interface of several discrete lattice models have SLE$_\kappa$ with different parameters $\kappa$ as their scaling limits. The current project focuses on studying the geometric properties of SLE curves, which will give people better understanding of those lattice models.

There are several versions of SLE: a chordal (resp. radial) SLE grows in a simply connected domain from one boundary point to a boundary (resp. interior) point; a whole-plane SLE grows in the Riemann sphere from one interior point to another interior point. The first major outcome of the project is that for $\kappa\in(0,4]$, a whole-plane SLE$_\kappa$ curve satisfies reversibility, i.e., the time-reversal of a whole-plane SLE$_\kappa$ curve from $a$ to $b$ has the same law as a whole-plane SLE$_\kappa$ curve from $b$ to $a$. The proof uses the coupling technique developed by the PI in earlier work on the reversibility of chordal SLE.

In another work joint with Steffen Rohde, the PI uses the coupling technique to study backward SLE, which is defined by adding a minus sign to the Loewner’s equation in the definition of a forward SLE. The joint paper shows that for $\kappa\in(0,4]$, the conformal welding generated by a backward SLE$_\kappa$ satisfies time-reversal symmetry for all $\kappa\in(0,4]$. This result was later used in the PI’s solo paper to study the forward SLE curve. He proved that the tip of an SLE curve at a fixed capacity time behaves like the initial part of a whole-plane SLE curve with some force at the origin.

For $\kappa\in(0,8)$ and a fixed interior point $z$, the probability that an SLE$_\kappa$ curve visits the small disc $B(z,r)$ decays like $r^\alpha$ as $r\to 0$ for $\alpha=1-\kappa/8$, and the limit as $r\to 0$ of $r^{-\alpha}$ times this probability exists, and is called the (one-point) Green’s function for SLE. In a series of works joint with Mohammad Rezaei, the PI studied the probability that a chordal SLE curve passes through a finite collection of small discs, and proves that the corresponding multi-point Green’s function exists. Moreover, the works derived the convergence rate of the multi-point Green’s function, and obtained sharp bounds of the Green’s function expressed in a simple formula.

In a recent work, the PI studied the Green’s function for a $2$-SLE configuration. A $2$-SLE$_\kappa$ is a pair of random curves in a simply connected domain connecting two pairs of boundary point such that when any curve is given, the other curve is a chordal SLE$_\kappa$ curve in the complement domain. The work shows that for $\alpha=(12-\kappa)(\kappa+4)/(8\kappa)$, the limit as $r\to 0$ of $r^{-\alpha}$ times the probability that the two curves both pass through the small disc exists and is not trivial. The limit is called a two-curve Green’s function, and its exact formula is obtained up to a multiplicative constant.

In a series of papers, the PI obtained a number of interesting results. The first paper proves that a chordal SLE curve admits a decomposition w.r.t. the capacity parametrization and a decomposition w.r.t. the natural parametrization. The latter decomposition involves two-sided radial SLE$_\kappa$, which is a kind of SLE$_\kappa$ connecting an interior point with two boundary points. The result says that if one integrates two-sided radial SLE$_\kappa$ passing through different interior points against the SLE Green’s function, then he gets a chordal SLE$_\kappa$ curve biased by its total length in Minkowski content.

In the second paper the PI used the decomposition result to construct several kinds of SLE loop measures. An SLE$_\kappa$ loop measure is an infinite measure on loops, which locally look like an SLE$_\kappa$ curve. The construction starts with rooted loops in the Riemann sphere. Among other nice properties, a rooted SLE$_\kappa$ loop measure satisfies the space-time homogeneity, i.e., if one samples a random point on the loop according to its Minkowski content, and shift this random point to the original root, then the new loop measure has the same law as the old measure. SLE loop measures are also defined in subdomains of the Riemann sphere and in general Riemann surface using Brownian loop measures.

A byproduct of the construction of SLE loop measures is an SLE$_\kappa$ ($\kappa\in(0,8)$) curve $\gamma$ with natural parametrization that satisfies self-similarity of index $1/d$, where $d=1+\kappa/8$, and has stationary increments. It is called an sssi SLE$_\kappa$ curve. Using such sssi SLE$_\kappa$ curve, the PI successfully proved that an SLE$_\kappa$ curve with natural parametrization is locally Hölder continuous of any order less than $1/d$. The PI also proved a theorem that resembles the double dimension theorem for Brownian motion: for any closed set $A$ in the real line, the Hausdorff dimension of $\gamma(A)$ equals $d$ times that of $A$.
